verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
verses.comment: Eliphaz is the first of Job’s friends to respond, initiating a lengthy discourse on suffering and justice.

verses.text: "If someone tries a word with you, will you be offended? But who can hold back from speaking?
verses.comment: Eliphaz gently tries to prepare Job for his following counsel, hinting at the delicate nature of advising a suffering friend.

verses.text: Look, you have instructed many, and you have strengthened weak hands.
verses.comment: Eliphaz appeals to Job’s wisdom and compassion for the afflicted, implying that now Job must apply to himself what he has taught others (cf. Gal. 6:2).

verses.text: Your words have upheld those who were stumbling, and you have made feeble knees strong.
verses.comment: Job’s former encouragement echoes in the prophets and New Testament, where strengthening the weak is a mark of true righteousness.

verses.text: But now it has come to you, and you are dismayed; it touches you, and you are troubled.
verses.comment: Eliphaz gently notes the irony that the sufferer becomes distressed, even after comforting others—a common human weakness, as seen even among the apostles.

verses.text: Is not your fear of God your confidence, and the integrity of your ways your hope?
verses.comment: He appeals to Job’s reverence and uprightness, reminding us that trust in God’s justice is foundational for hope, much as Christ placed all confidence in His Father (cf. Mk. 14:36).

verses.text: Remember: Who that was innocent ever perished? Or where were the upright destroyed?
verses.comment: Eliphaz expresses the common belief of reward for righteousness, though this is challenged by Job’s experience. The ultimate Innocent Sufferer, Christ Himself, fulfills and transforms this expectation (cf. Is. 53:9; 2 Cor. 5:21).

verses.text: As I have seen, those who plow iniquity and sow trouble reap the same.
verses.comment: This proverbial saying echoes through Scripture, but in light of Christ’s Passion, suffering cannot always be traced directly to personal sin.

verses.text: By the breath of God they perish, and by the blast of his anger they are consumed.
verses.comment: God’s sovereign power brings judgment; cf. the destruction in the flood (Gen. 6–7) and fire from heaven (Gen. 19).

verses.text: The roar of the lion, the voice of the fierce lion, and the teeth of the young lions are broken.
verses.comment: Lions symbolize the mighty and proud; Scripture often portrays God humbling the powerful (cf. Dan. 4:30–37).

verses.text: The strong lion perishes for lack of prey, and the whelps of the lioness are scattered.
verses.comment: The imagery reinforces that prosperity and power offer no immunity to judgment; rather, all are subject to God’s providence.

verses.text: "Now a word came stealthily to me; my ear received a whisper of it.
verses.comment: Eliphaz introduces what appears to be a revelation—a mysterious or prophetic dream—reflecting a belief in ongoing divine communication.

verses.text: Amid thoughts from visions of the night, when deep sleep falls on men,
verses.comment: Nighttime visions often signal the supernatural in the Old Testament (e.g., Abraham, Daniel), pointing to God’s initiative in revelation.

verses.text: Dread came upon me, and trembling, which made all my bones shake.
verses.comment: Such an encounter inspires real fear; compare with the awe of those in Scripture who encounter angels or the divine (cf. Lk. 1:12; Ex. 3:6).

verses.text: A spirit passed before my face; the hair of my flesh stood up.
verses.comment: The ancient world recognized spiritual realities, and even a fleeting presence could provoke terror—a sign of the transcendent.

verses.text: It stood still, but I could not discern its appearance. A form was before my eyes; there was silence, then I heard a voice:
verses.comment: Mystery surrounds genuine encounters with the divine or the angelic, often more than can be easily understood—preparing for revealed truth.

verses.text: "Can mortal man be righteous before God? Can a man be pure before his Maker?
verses.comment: Here lies the deep question of human righteousness—no human, apart from grace, is perfectly righteous before God (see also Rom. 3:10-23). This anticipates the need for a Redeemer who is both fully man and fully God.

verses.text: Even in his servants he puts no trust, and his angels he charges with error;
verses.comment: God’s holiness, before which even angels may be found wanting, points to creation's dependence on the Creator and sets the stage for the doctrine of grace.

verses.text: how much more those who dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, who are crushed more quickly than a moth!
verses.comment: Humankind’s frailty, coming from the dust of the earth, points to our mortality and constant need for God’s mercy and for sanctifying grace.

verses.text: Between morning and evening they are shattered; they perish forever without anyone regarding it.
verses.comment: Human life is described as fleeting—a major theme in wisdom literature, and which Christ answers with the promise of resurrection (cf. Jn. 5:28-29).

verses.text: Is not their tent-cord pulled up within them, so that they die, and that without wisdom?
verses.comment: Here life is likened to a tent quickly taken down, echoing Paul’s image (2 Cor. 5:1-4), and pointing to the greater home for the just after death—the hope of those who trust in God’s saving work.
